intro: Calamaria lacustris, commonly known as the water calamaria, is a flowering plant native to wetland environments. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its slender, herbaceous stems and clusters of bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, adapting to aquatic or semi-aquatic conditions. Its flowers are usually blue or purple, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Calamaria lacustris plays an important role in wetland ecosystems by providing habitat and contributing to biodiversity.
